discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
After termination, offboarding.

questions.question_text: Which of the following policies would be best to refer to when trying to prevent a disgruntled employee from copying sensitive materials off company servers after termination?
Which of the following routing protocols uses attributes to select the best path?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Idk why or how or who or f comptia.

Selected Answer: B
BGP uses various attributes, such as AS-PATH, NEXT-HOP, LOCAL_PREF, and others, to determine the best path for routing decisions.
BGP literally says in its definition it uses attributes for its metrics.
OSPF for sure. Not debatable

Selected Answer: B
BGP is correct.

Selected Answer: C
Unless I'm dumb, OSPF, open shortest path first easy question. Dont think too hard about it, the rest are protocols. next question

comments.content: Changing answer to BGP just bc other online answers say the same thing. I honest to god dont completely understand what "attributes" are but that's the reason

OSPF is a protocol too. All 4 of these are routing protocols. And also based on your reasoning would instantly cancel out OSPF. 

RIP uses hop counts for it's metric
OSPF uses cost for it's metric
EIGRP uses vectors (which is a combination of a few things) for it's metric
BGP is the only routing protocol I could see that actively uses the word attribute to determine it's routing.

B: BGP is the correct answer
Console port is part of the management plane, yes.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=23H0nA-_4YE&t=42s

Professor messer vid explains the consol port is most likely the management plane

Selected Answer: D
The console port is closely associated with the management plane as it provides direct access to the device for administrative tasks such as configuration and troubleshooting.

Selected Answer: D
The component most closely associated with the management plane is the Console port. It is primarily used for managing and configuring network devices.

This is pretty meta, which is annoying but the focus here I think is on "closely associated with" - which would be a console port because the idea behind the management plane is Management. Current config IMO would be the control plane

Selected Answer: B
The console port (D) is actually associated with the management plane as well, since it is used to access and manage a device's configuration. However, the console port is more of a physical interface for accessing the management plane rather than a part of the management plane itself.

This is why I think B is right. That's my take on this question anyway. Suggested to do your own research and make your own choice not just follow what 1 person says.

Selected Answer: B
Current configuration, i wish C. said network operations -

comments.content:
Yes and part of the management plane is the console connection/port. The management port and console port work in tandem together to create the management plane. Correct answer is D.

If it said updating configuration then B would make sense too. But it says current config which implies the config that is sitting there installed on the device.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Current configuration. The management plane handles administrative tasks, including configuration management, monitoring, and control of network devices. The current configuration represents the settings and parameters that define how a device operates, and managing it is essential for maintaining network functionality and security

questions.question_text: Which of the following is most closely associated with the management plane?

A technician is working on a ticket for a user in the human resources department who received a new PC that does not connect to the internet. All users in human resources can access the internet. The technician can ping the PC from the human resources router but not from the IT network. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
this has to be D. it can ping the router on the same net or subnet but cannot connect outside the net IE routing problems bad gateway settings. correct me if wrong.
Can't get out of it's own subnet, you have a GW issue. D.

comments.content: To be clear, there **are** scenarios where you could have devices in different VLANs talk directly to different subnets, but those aren't the norm and are usually misconfigurations.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
It's D. 

Pretending the HR VLAN is .10 and IT VLAN is .20, a device with the wrong VLAN (pretend .30) wouldn't be able to talk to the HR router in the first place.

If it has the wrong default gateway, then it can send data on the HR VLAN (.10) but any data destined outside of that VLAN wouldn't be routed.

Selected Answer: D
PC can be pinged from the local router - L3 addressing works locally and PC is on the HR vlan. BUT PC can not go out to the internet and can not be pinged from outside the HR network, meaning traffic can not leave the HR router. Therefore the gateway is incorrect.

comments.content:
And this is why it can't be C. A computer in the wrong VLAN would not be reachable from the HR one. 
So if you can reach the computer from HR, then it means it's in the same VLAN, which only leaves D as the viable answer, since a proper gateway is required to connect to the internet, which is the issue they're having here.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The fact that the technician can ping the PC from the human resources router but not from the IT network suggests that the PC might be on a different VLAN (Virtual Local Area Network). VLANs are used to logically separate devices on a network. If the new PC was not properly assigned to the correct VLAN, it would not be able to communicate with devices outside of its VLAN, hence the inability to connect to the internet.

Selected Answer: C
C. Improper VLAN assignment.

Selected Answer: D
id go with D
I would go with D

Selected Answer: C
N has been the answer for most of these questions.

Selected Answer: C
802.11n only 5ghz

Selected Answer: C
C. Its the only one that supports a 5GHz signal
